School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University of Engineering Science Shanghai 201620 PR China A series of metal foam-supported Ni-based catalysts-monometallic Ni-CF, bimetallic Ni/Ce-CF, Ni/Al-CF and trimetallic Ni/Ce/Al-CF-were prepared by modified wet chemical etching (MWCE) and employed for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition (MD) in the temperature range of 200–325 ℃. Among those catalysts, the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-Cu foam (CF) catalyst shows the superior catalytic performance for hydrogen production, achieving a remarkable activity of almost complete methanol conversion (99.3 %) and high H2 selectivity of 91.8 % at 300 ℃. Moreover, the performance of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst remained stable during the stability test for up to 40 h at 275 ℃. SEM and BET characterization show that etched copper foam can remarkably enlarge the specific surface area of the structured catalyst, provide more active sites, and enhance its catalytic activity. The strong interaction among Ni, Ce and Al induce the synergistic effect by creating abundant oxygen vacancies in the trimetallic system as evidenced by XPS. H2-TPR and XPS further revealed a crucial balance between reducibility and metal-support interactions: Al-containing catalysts like 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF exhibit higher reduction thresholds and confirming the role of Al in stabilizing oxidized Ni species via strong metal-support interactions. And CH3OH-TPD analysis indicated the catalyst had much higher low-temperature hydrogen production than other catalysts because of the synergistic effect of three metals, consistent with the catalyst activity test results. The developed strategy may provide insights into the development of the design principles for high-performance structured catalysts for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition. Graphical Abstract Keywords Methanol decomposition Ni-based catalysts Structured catalysts Synergy effect Hydrogen production Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The over-reliance on fossil fuels to sustain the economic growth and development of human society has led to extensive environmental and societal challenges, including climate change, air pollution and energy scarcity [1,2]. Consequently, there is an urgent need to transition to sustainable, efficient and low-carbon energy sources [3,4]. Hydrogen has emerged as a promising clean energy carrier for sustainable energy solutions, particularly in applications such as internal combustion engines[5]. Pure hydrogen engines offer significant environmental advantages, as hydrogen combustion produces virtually no carbon-related emissions—eliminating carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide(CO2) [6]. This positions hydrogen as a key solution for mitigating climate change and improving air quality[7]. The automotive industry faces growing pressure to comply with stringent emission regulations, such as those set by the European Union. Consequently, major manufacturers, including Cummins, Reliance, and Ashok Leyland, are investing in hydrogen engine research and development (R&D), particularly for heavy-duty vehicles, to achieve zero-carbon emissions [8]. However, the widespread adoption of pure hydrogen engines is hindered by significant technical challenges, including abnormal combustion phenomena such as pre-ignition, knocking, and backfire; material compatibility issues such as hydrogen embrittlement and lubrication system degradation; and the requirement for efficient high-pressure storage or cryogenic systems [9]. These challenges collectively necessitate innovative engineering solutions to advance the practical implementation of hydrogen engine technology. Hydrogen, as a pure fuel for internal combustion engines, faces significant challenges faces significant challenges: its low reactivity and delayed ignition may lead to inefficient combustion processes and inherent drawbacks in terms of engine compatibility [10]. These limitations restrict the direct application of pure hydrogen as a feasible fuel for conventional internal combustion systems. Recently, hydrogen-blended fuels, such as ammonia-hydrogen mixtures, have demonstrated superior combustion performance through optimized fuel reactivity and energy density [9]. Lately using methanol as a clean energy carrier has gained increasing attention, as methanol can be produced from renewable resources such as biomass or captured carbon dioxide, offering a potentially sustainable and carbon-neutral fuel source [11]. The synergistic effects of hydrogen blending with liquid fuels such as methanol not only enhance flame propagation and ignition characteristics but also mitigate thermodynamic challenges associated with pure hydrogen combustion, thereby enabling more efficient energy conversion and reduced operational demands on engine components. The integration of methanol-to-hydrogen production with internal combustion engine requirements can enable on-board hydrogen production. Methanol decomposition is a promising technological approach to the on-board production of hydrogen fuel for internal combustion engines, a versatile fuel recognized as a viable alternative to conventional fossil fuels [12,13]. This reaction involves the cleavage of carbon-hydrogen bonds in the molecule to produce hydrogen and carbon monoxide, a process that can be facilitated by various noble metal and transition metal catalysts. Cai et al. [14] synthesized Pt/MoC catalysts with different Pt loads, and catalysts with lower Pt loads promoted the formation of more α-MoC1-x. This results in a highly dispersed Pt active substance and an enhanced interaction between the active substance and the carrier, leading to 88.2 % methanol conversion at 240 ℃. Carraro et al. [15] designed a Pd/CeO2 catalyst using nanostructured ceria supports to enhance methanol decomposition performance. The 5 wt% Pd/CeO2 small nanorods achieved a 50 % methanol conversion at 150 ℃ with 99.8 % CO selectivity and an activation energy of 41 kJ/mol, outperforming previously reported Pd-based catalysts. However, despite its exceptional low-temperature activity and selectivity, the use of large amount of expensive group VIII precious metals (e.g., Pt and Pd) introduces significant cost barriers, limiting its practical application despite its superior performance [16]. To address this cost issue and make the technology more viable for widespread use, researchers have turned their attention to alternative catalysts. Transition metal Cu-based catalysts have emerged as a promising solution. Previous studies have indicated that Cu-based catalysts [17–19], like CuAl and CuZnAl, typically exhibit high catalytic activity for hydrogen generation through methanol decomposition in the temperature interval of 200–300 ℃.Wang et al. [19] found that all the CuAl catalysts prepared by different methods exhibited serious activity loss for methanol decomposition at 270 ℃ over 70 h time on stream, attributable to the sintering of Cu particles. Qing et al. [20] prepared a Cu/SiO2 catalyst via impregnation using starch-modified SiO2. The initial methanol conversion rate of the catalyst was 98.4 % at 300 ℃. However, at elevated temperature of 300 ℃, irreversible copper sintering occurred due to its low Tammann temperature (405 ℃), with decreasing hydrogen production rates over time. Coking may also occur in an irregular trend in Cu-based catalysts, accelerating the catalyst deactivation in the initial and final stages due to support impurities and structural changes. These combined factors caused distinct deactivation patterns at different reaction stages. Herein, motivated by the challenges of cost barriers inherent in noble metal systems and structural instability in Cu-based catalysts, considerable efforts have been devoted to designing and developing cost-effective and robust alternative nickel-based catalysts for sustainable hydrogen production via methanol decomposition by synergistically addressing thermal degradation limitations through enhanced metal-support interactions [21,22]. Nickel-based catalysts demonstrate superior performance in methanol decomposition compared to conventional hydrogen production technologies. Mitani et al. [23] studied Ni-25Fe and Ni-15Fe-13Mg alloy nanoparticles for methanol decomposition, and found that the Ni-15Fe-13Mg catalyst achieved 90 % methanol conversion (vs. 60 % for Ni-25Fe catalysts) with lower carbon deposition at 753 K. The enhanced activity of Ni-15Fe-13Mg originates from Mg segregating, which forms a surface MgO shell, which suppresses nanoparticle coarsening, maintains a high active surface area and provides structural stability through synergistic effects. Xu et al. [24] engineered Ni-Al nanoparticles via arc plasma evaporation. These Ni-based catalysts achieved near-complete methanol conversion (> 98 % hydrogen selectivity) at 713 K. The synergistic metal-support interaction between Ni phases and Al2O3 matrices confers exceptional structural stability, effectively suppressing carbon deposition while maintaining catalytic activity over 200 h of continuous operation. Michalska-Domańska et al. [25] reported that the microcrystalline Ni3Al thin foils exhibited good catalytic properties in methanol decomposition, with a conversion rate of 94 % at 500 ℃. The catalyst retained high efficiency despite carbon deposition, forming multi-walled carbon nanotubes and nanofibers that encapsulated Ni nanoparticles, maintaining active sites. Rojas et al. [26] reported that Ni/LDO and Ni/B-LDO catalysts featuring 5 %, 10 %, and 20 % nickel loadings on boron-modified hydrotalcite-derived mixed oxides exhibited 90–100 % methanol conversion at 450 ℃ during decomposition, with Ni/B-LDO catalysts demonstrating nearly 100 % conversion at 350 ℃. To sum up, a major limitation of these Ni-based catalysts is the requirement of high reaction temperature[27–29]. Therefore, developing low-temperature Ni-based catalysts for methanol decomposition to achieve more energy-efficient and cost-effective hydrogen production is urgently needed. Catalytic systems utilizing metallic foam substrates have garnered significant attention in recent years as a promising alternative to conventional catalyst supports, driven by the growing demand for efficient heterogeneous catalysts in energy conversion and environmental remediation applications [30]. This emerging interest stems from the unique structural advantages offered by three-dimensional porous metallic frameworks, which combine high surface-to-volume ratios with exceptional thermal/electrical conductivity and mechanical durability-properties that address critical limitations of traditional pellet or powder catalysts while enabling novel reactor design possibilities. Tang et al. [31] engineered a hierarchical CeAlOx/Ni/Ni-foam catalyst for CO2 methanation, capitalizing on the intrinsic thermal conductivity and continuous porosity of Ni foam to mitigate thermal gradients in exothermic reactions. At 240 ℃ and a GHSV of 80,000 h−1, the system achieved 80 % CO2 conversion with 98.6 % CH4 selectivity, delivering a 14-fold enhancement in space-time yield relative to conventional Ni/CeAlOx pellets. Yang et al. [32] developed silver-modified NiCo2O4 nanosheets supported on 3D microporous Ni foam for soot combustion, leveraging the interconnected structure of the foam to enhance gas-solid contact. The high porosity (>98 %) and mechanical robustness of the nickel foam provided a stable platform for cross-linked NiCo2O4 nanosheets, creating abundant contact points with soot particles and facilitating mass transfer. The catalyst maintained high stability over five cycles, retaining T50 (temperature for 50 % soot conversion) within 333–336 ℃ minimal structural degradation. These results highlight the synergistic benefits the 3D architecture of Ni foam and Ag modification for efficient soot oxidation. Li et al. [33] developed a structured Ni-CeO2-Al2O3/Ni-foam catalyst via modified wet-chemical etching, leveraging the high thermal conductivity of Ni foam to address heat transfer limitations in syngas methanation. This catalyst achieved > 99 % CO conversion and 93 % methane selectivity at 300 ℃ under a GHSV of 5000 h−1, comparable to particulate Ni-CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts but with superior thermal stability. After 1500 h of operation, it retained > 99 % CO conversion and showed minimal sintering, with Ni particles (8–10 nm) uniformly distributed on the foam structures. The aforementioned metal foams are offer a promising avenue for developing of novel monolithic catalysts and reactor technologies for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition. However, achieving effective and efficient coating methods to load catalytic active sites onto metal-foam structures remains highly desirable and significantly challenging. Herein, we propose a facile protocol to catalytically functionalize monolithic copper foams via a modified wet chemical etching method to directly synthesizing 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-Cu foam catalysts on their structures. To further enhance the activity and stability of Ni-based catalysts for low-temperature methanol decomposition, cerium and aluminum were deliberately selected as co-modifiers. CeO2 is well known for its high oxygen storage capacity and facile Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycling, promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and improves the activation of methanol molecules [34]. Al2O3 provides a high surface area support and contributes to the structural stabilization of the catalyst, suppressing Ni particle sintering during high-temperature operation [35]. More importantly, the interaction between Ce and Al can create a more defective lattice that promotes synergistic effects among the three metal components. These unique features underpin the novelty of the trimetallic 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF system in the context of efficient hydrogen production under mild conditions. The representative 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-Cu foam catalyst not only exhibits activity and selectivity comparable to conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, along with excellent stability, high permeability and enhanced heat transfer. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical reagents Ce(NO3)3•6 H2O (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99 %), Al(NO3)3•9 H2O (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99 %), Ni(NO3)3•6 H2O (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99 %) were used as precursors in the synthesis of the catalysts. The Cu foam (copper content 99.8 %;130 pores per inch (PPI); 1.5 mm thickness, 6.0 mm diameter equal to the reactor inner diameter of quartz tube (6.0 mm) respectively. And sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS, ALDRICH Chemistry), Acetic acid (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99.7 %), acetone (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99.7 %), Hydrochloric acid (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99.7 %), GC-grade methanol (ALDRICH Chemistry, purity 99.9 %) and high-purity gases supplied by Air Liquide (N2, Ar, He and H2) were used in the catalytic activity tests. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis The thin-sheet metal-foam-structured catalysts were fabricated on a macro-scale using our MWCE method followed by thermal treatment for activation [33]. This method was developed based on the wet chemical etching technique. Metal foam chips of copper (Cu) were obtained from their large parent sheets by mechanical cutting and sonicated in acetone for 10 min to remove residual surface organic impurities. These circular slices were then immersed in a 3 M HCl solution at room temperature for an additional 10 min of sonication to remove the surface copper oxide layer from the Cu foam, followed by thorough rinsing with deionized water. These metal-foam chips were respectively immersed into the chemical etching solutions and held at 65 ℃ for 3 h. The chemical etching solution consisting of 1.0 mmol L−1 sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS, C12H25-OSO3Na), 0.2 mol L−1 acetic acid (CH3COOH),0.3 mol L−1 aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3),0.3 mol L−1 cerous nitrate (Ce(NO3)3) and such solution with nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2) adding to a concentration of 0.2 mol L−1 was utilized for the Cu-foam. After wet chemical etching, the resulting foams were dried overnight at 80 ℃, followed by calcining in air at 350 ℃ for 2 h. The corresponding catalysts are denoted as 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF. The synthesized catalysts were designated as Ni-CF, Ni/Ce-CF, Ni/Al-CF, and Ni/Ce/Al-CF, where CF denotes the copper foam support matrix and numerical indices specify the molar ratio of promoter metals. A uniform synthesis protocol was employed to fabricate these metallic foam-supported Ni-based catalysts with varying promoter metal compositions. Specifically, the nomenclature convention adopts the following format: Ni-(Promoter1/Promoter2)-CF, where the absence of promoter designation indicates a monometallic system, while the inclusion of dual promoters (e.g., Ce/Al) signifies their co-existence with specified molar ratios. 2.3 Characterization techniques The structures of the synthesized catalysts were characterized by various physicochemical methods. (a) Scanning electron microscope (SEM) were tested by ZEISS in Germany. (b) X-ray diffraction (XRD): Powder XRD patterns were recorded on a Bruker D2 Phaser diffractometer (Germany) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). Data were collected in the 2θ range of 20–90° with a step size of 0.02° and a scan rate of 0.1°·min−1. Phase identification was performed using Jade 6.5 software, and crystallite sizes were calculated via the Scherrer equation. (c) The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 at 77 K. The specific surface areas (SBET), pore volume (VP) and pore diameter (DP) were calculated from the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner Halenda (BJH) models. The catalysts pretreatment were degassed at 350 ℃ for 4 h to remove the adsorbed surface residues. (d) The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Cu Kα source. The XPS spectra were analyzed using the Avantage software package and all the binding energies of elements were referenced to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. (e) The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) determined the catalysts reducibility by using chemical adsorption instrument (Micromeritics Autochem II 2920). Ten chips of catalysts were charged into a U-shaped fixed-bed quartz microreactor and preheated at 300 ℃ with Ar (30 ml·min−1) for 30 min, then cooled to 50 ℃. Thereafter, the catalyst was exposed to 10 % H2/Ar (30 ml·min−1), and heated from 50 to 900 ℃ (10 ℃·min−1). A cold trap was placed before TCD and the variation in H2 uptake was monitored using TCD as a function of temperature. (f) Temperature programmed desorption of CH3OH (CH3OH-TPD) was tested by means of chemical adsorption instrument coupled with a mass spectrometry (Hiden HPR20). Catalyst was charged into a U-shaped fixed-bed quartz microreactor, pretreated at 350 ℃ for 0.5 h in 10 % H2/Ar (30 ml·min−1), and cooled to RT, and then continue to purge for 40 min (30 ml·min−1). Thereafter, the pretreated catalysts were exposed to 4.5 % CH3OH/Ar, purged with He at RT for 30 min, and then heated to 900 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃·min−1 with. The products were detected by mass spectrometry based on their characteristic mass fragmentations, corresponding to the m/e values of 60 (CH3OOCH), 46 (HCOOH), 45 (CH3OCH3), 44 (CO2), 31 (CH3OH), 30 (H2CO), 28 (CO), 18 (H2O), 15 (CH4) and 2 (H2). (g) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the used catalysts was performed on a Simultaneous TG-DTA/DSC Apparatus (High Temperature Platform 400, STA 449 F3 Jupiter, NETZSCH-Gerätebau GmbH). 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Gas chromatography at normal atmospheric pressure was used to evaluate the catalytic activity of the catalyst for MD. Ten Cu foam catalysts were placed in a quartz tube with a flowing inner diameter of 6.0 mm. The activity test was conducted by gradually increasing the temperature within the range of 200–325 ℃. The liquid pump continuously fed the methanol in the required molar ratio and reacted with the catalyst after gasification in the vaporization chamber. The temperature of the evaporator and the temperature of the heating zone used in the reaction pipeline were maintained at 120 ℃. The reactants and products in the system were analyzed online by the gas chromatograph. Reproducibility was within an acceptable range (±2.0 %) with each temperature point tested twice. The reactor products underwent quantitative analysis using a gas chromatograph (GC9800). The following formulae were used to calculate methanol conversion, product selectivity, and space-time yield (STY): (1) X C H 3 OH ( % ) = C in ( C H 3 OH ) − C out ( C H 3 OH ) C in ( C H 3 OH ) × 100 (2) Product selectivity ( % ) = v i C i ∑ all production species v i C j × 100 (3) STY ( mol H 2 g cat − 1 · h − 1 ) = F CH 3 OH × X CH 3 OH × n H 2 × S H 2 m cat Cin (CH3OH) represents the molar flux of CH3OH at the inlet, while Cout (CH3OH) represents the molar flux of CH3OH at the outlet. The molar flux of the product is represented by Vi (mol⋅min−1), and Ci represents the quantity of C or H atoms. F(CH3OH) represents the molar feed rate of methanol (mol·h−1); X(CH3OH) is the methanol conversion; n(H2) represents the number of H2 molecules theoretically generated per CH3OH molecule; S(H2) represents the selectivity of hydrogen; m(cat) stands for the mass of catalyst used in the reaction (g). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SEM imaging The catalyst morphology was characterized by SEM analysis. Fig. 1 presents the SEM images of the foam structure and the as-prepared 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst. As shown in Fig. A1–A3, the untreated CF catalyst showed well-preserved monolithic structure with a smooth surface, and its textural features were characteristic of 130 PPI, surface density of 650 g·m−2. In Fig. B1–B3, the surface of the monometallic 2Ni-CF catalyst appears rather smooth. In contrast, the surfaces of the bimetallic 2Ni/3 Al-CF (Fig. C1-C3) and 2Ni/3Ce-CF (Fig. D1-D2) catalysts became rougher. Notably, the trimetallic 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst (Fig. E1-E3) exhibits an even greater surface roughness than the bimetallic counterparts. Apparently, after undergoing wet chemical etching and calcination, the foam structure surface exhibits roughness and is fully covered by a highly uniform porous layer made of cube-like nanocrystals (scale bars: 2 μm). The roughening of the surface and the formation of a porous layer can provide more active sites for catalytic reactions by increasing the specific surface area of the catalyst, thereby significantly enhancing catalytic activity. The enhanced surface roughness and porosity align with pore-engineering strategies reported for MOFs [36], where optimized mass transfer pathways improve catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, the nanocrystalline porous layer contributes to structural stability [37]. Elemental mapping ( Fig. 2) confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Ce, and Al across the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst, indicating successful integration of all metallic components. 3.2 BET Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalysts, with detailed textural parameters summarized in Table 1. Fig. 3A (etched) and Fig. 3B (unetched) show the etched 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF and the unetched copper foam catalyst and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. The catalysts show a typical type IV isotherm classified according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), as demonstrated by the presence of a clear capillary condensation step in the P/P 0 region of 0.4–0.5 [38]. In addition, hysteresis loops with adsorption and desorption branches indicate a narrow pore size distribution (4–8 nm) calculated from the desorption branch using the BJH model [39]. It can be seen from Fig. 3 that the etched catalysts have mesoporous structures with uniform pore size distribution, indicating that the mesoporous structure of the catalyst has been created resulting from etching treatment [40]. In addition, Table 1 summarizes the SBET, VP, and DP calculated by BET and BJH models of the two catalysts respectively. As can be observed from Table 1, The etched catalyst demonstrates a significantly higher specific surface area (SBET=19.2621 m2·g−1) compared to the unetched counterpart (SBET=0.2465 m2·g−1), accompanied by increased pore volume (VP: 0.038313 vs. 0.001318 cm3·g−1) and uniform mesopores (DP: 6.4191 vs. 8.0021 nm). This finding is consistent with the SEM results (Fig. 1E), suggesting that in the presence of Ni, Ce, Al, and other substances, the etching treatment effectively enhances the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts [41]. A higher specific surface area generally facilitates the formation of active sites [42], which is beneficial for the occurrence of heterogeneous reactions [43]. 3.3 X-ray diffraction XRD analysis was performed to identify crystalline phases and evaluate the dispersion state of metallic components in the catalysts. The XRD patterns were analyzed to investigate the phase structures of the blank copper foam and the prepared catalysts. For the blank copper foam, characteristic diffraction peaks were observed at 43.32 °, 50.36 °, and 74.04 °, which can be indexed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of face-centered cubic copper (PDF No. 65–9026), respectively. When examining the monometallic, bimetallic, and trimetallic catalysts, no additional diffraction peaks other than those from the copper foam substrate were detected. The absence of distinct diffraction signals for Al and Ce species suggests that these elements are highly dispersed at the nanoscale or exist in an amorphous state within the catalyst structure, preventing the formation of crystalline phases with detectable sizes [44]. Notably, the diffraction features of Ni (PDF No. 01–3035) and Cu exhibit significant overlap due to their similar face-centered cubic crystal structures, making it difficult to distinguish individual contributions from these two metals through XRD alone. This observation is consistent with the EDS results presented in Fig. 2, which confirm the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Ce, and Al across the catalyst surface [45]. The complementary characterization techniques collectively indicate that the introduced metal species maintain a well-dispersed state without forming large crystalline aggregates, which is crucial for maximizing their catalytic active sites and reactivity [46]. 3.4 XPS XPS analysis ( Fig. 5) was performed to probe the surface chemical states of Ni/Ce/Al-CF catalysts, with quantitative peak fitting applied to deconvolute species. The Ni 2p XPS spectra presented in Fig. 5A distinctly reveal the valence state evolution of nickel species across the catalyst surfaces. As quantified by the Ni2+/NiTotal ratios summarized in Table 3, the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst exhibits a Ni2+ proportion of 71.89 %, intermediate between the 66.13 % of 2Ni/3Al-CF and 89.03 % of 2Ni/3Ce-CF, while the 2Ni-CF catalyst shows 100 % Ni2+ content. Notably, the 100 % Ni2+ content in the 2Ni-CF catalyst may be attributed to rapid reoxidation of reduced Ni0 species upon exposure to air in short time prior to XPS measurement, even the catalyst was pre-reduced under hydrogen atmosphere. Although our current XPS analysis provides evidence of Ni2+ and Ni0 species on the catalyst surface, it does not capture dynamic valence state changes during the reaction. The dynamic valence state transitions between Ni2+ and Ni0 may enable surface regeneration and redox cycling, and merit further investigation through in-situ or near-ambient pressure spectroscopic techniques. In Fig. 5B, the O 1 s spectra of 2Ni-CF catalysts were fitted into three peaks, respectively, centered at about 533.28, 531.37 and 529.69 eV [47,48]. Based on the literature, the peak near at 529 eV was assigned to the surface lattice oxygen (Olattice) in the oxygen form, the peak near at 531 eV was assigned to the surface vacancy oxygen(Ovacancy) in the oxygen form and the peak near at 533 eV was assigned to the weakly bound oxygen(OH) in the oxygen form [49]. The density of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst can also be calculated from the O 1 s spectra in terms of Ovacancy/ (Ovacancy+ Olattice+OH). Table 3 shows that the percentage of oxygen vacancies is 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF > 2Ni/3Al-CF > 2Ni/3Ce-CF > 2Ni-CF. As shown in the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra (Fig. S1), the relative intensity of oxygen vacancies exhibits a consistent trend. As has been reported in many literatures, the surface oxygen vacancy concentration of catalysts can be deduced from the fitted Ce 3d XPS spectra. As shown in Fig. 5C, the Ce 3d spectra can be decomposed into 10 groups, because the electronic structure of the Ce 3d orbitals is affected by the hybridization between the Ce 4 f orbitals and the O 2p valence band [50]. The five peaks labeled 1(880.8 eV), 2 (882.4 eV), 3(885.3 eV), 4(889.0 eV) and 5 (898.4 eV) belong to Ce 3d5/2, The other five peaks labeled 1’ (899.1 eV), 2’(900.7 eV), 3’(903.6 eV), 4’(907.3 eV), and 5’ (916.7 eV) are assigned to Ce 3d3/2 [51,52]. Of these ten peaks, 1, 1’, 3, and 3’ are derived from the Ce3+ species (Ce2O3), while the remaining six peaks correspond to the Ce4+ species (CeO2) [53]. The surface Ce3+ density can be calculated based on the relationship Ce3+/Ce4+ between Ce4+ and Ce3+ peak area, and are presented in Table 3 [54,55]. Ce3+ concentration is related to surface oxygen vacancy, so the formation of oxygen vacancies is always accompanied by the formation of Ce3+ [56], and the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio in the CeO2 catalyst follows the order of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF> 2Ni/3Ce-CF, implying that the presence of Al favors the formation of the abundant surface Ce3+ species and surface oxygen vacancies. 3.5 H2-TPR H2-TPR analysis was used to examine the critical balance between reducibility and metal-support interactions that governs the catalytic functionality. As illustrated in Fig. 6, while 2Ni/3Ce-CF exhibits the lowest reduction temperature due to CeO2-mediated oxygen vacancies formation facilitating interfacial electron transfer, its comparatively lower hydrogen consumption suggests partial reduction limitation. Conversely, Al-containing catalysts demonstrate elevated reduction thresholds, aligning with XPS-derived Ni2+ content trends, which confirms the role of Al in stabilizing oxidized Ni species through strong metal-support interactions. Notably, Ce and Al co-promoted 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF achieve an optimal compromise with moderate reduction temperature and maximal hydrogen uptake [57]. This synergism likely originates from Ce-Al cooperative effects: Ce promotes reducibility via oxygen mobility while Al anchors Ni2+ species, preventing over-reduction to metallic Ni [58]. Such balanced redox behavior enables efficient activation of reactive intermediates while maintaining structural integrity during catalytic cycles. The structure-activity correlation is further supported by the inverse relationship between Ni2+ content and reducibility. Higher Ni2+ stabilization in Al-rich systems necessitates stronger driving forces for reduction, yet the intermediate reduction temperature in Ce-Al co-modified systems ensures sufficient active site availability. These findings underscore the importance of tailoring reducibility through promoters engineering to optimize active site accessibility and stability, thereby achieving superior catalytic functionality. Combined with the XPS results, the content of divalent nickel in the catalysts shows the following order: 2Ni-CF > 2Ni/3Al-CF > 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF > 2Ni/3Ce-CF. This indicates that the presence of Al may stabilize the divalent nickel in the catalysts. The catalysts containing Al are more difficult to reduce in H2-TPR, which is corroborated by the result of the relatively high content of divalent nickel in Al-containing catalysts in XPS. 3.6 CH3OH-TPD CH3OH-TPD was employed to investigate the influence of each component on the surface sites of the Ni/Ce/Al-CF series catalysts and to explore the methanol transformation process during methanol decomposition, as depicted in Fig. 7. In the low temperature range, CH3OH, H2, CO and CO2 were identified as the main desorption species, in which the desorbed methanol in its physical adsorption state was released quickly after thermal activation at low temperature of 49–62.7 ℃ over bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts. The generation of CO, CO2, and H2 in this interval indicates that the catalyst surface exhibits activity toward the cleavage of C–H bond [59]. At about 125 ℃, H2 and CO peak showed up simultaneously, indicating the reaction pathway of methanol decomposition at this temperature. In this figure, the peak intensities of H2 and CO over the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst are significantly higher than those of other catalysts, suggesting that this catalyst exhibits superior capability for hydrogen production at lower temperatures. Moreover, the formation of CO2 and CO can be attributed to the different reaction paths of methanol molecules over catalyst surface. CO and H2 were the decomposition product of gaseous formaldehyde which was generated from dehydrogenation of methoxy [60]. In contrast, CO2 may be derived from the product of adsorbed formaldehyde as formyl group reacting with surface hydroxyl group or originated from methoxy reacting with surface oxygen-containing species [61]. Undoubtedly, the surface hydroxyl in 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst is more reactive in the study of methanol desorption, and Ce addition promotes oxygen transfer from the ceria bulk to its surface and subsequently from the support surface to adjacent metal particles, thereby sustaining a high population of catalytically active partially oxidized metal species. 3.7 MD Performance analysis of catalysts The catalytic reactivity measurement was performed over a temperature range of 200–325 ℃, with the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2727 h−1. The methanol conversions are displayed in Fig. 8A. The selectivity of H2, CH4 and CO is depicted in Figs. 8B, 8C, 8D. The trimetallic catalyst and bimetallic catalysts revealed a higher methanol conversion than 2Ni-CF catalyst at all operating temperatures. For 2Ni/3Al-CF catalyst, the methanol conversion increased slowly from 42 % at 250 ℃ to 52 % at 275 ℃, then it showed an increase up to 81 % at 300 ℃. The 2Ni/3Ce-CF catalyst showed a steady increase in methanol conversion from 200 to 300 ℃, followed by a slower rise between 300 and 325 ℃. The difference of methanol conversion between the two bimetallic catalysts containing Ni is 2 %–12 % at low temperature of 200–275 ℃, and 13 %-30 % at high temperature of 300–325 ℃, indicating that the interaction between Ni and Al is more beneficial to methanol decomposition than the interaction between Ni and Ce [62]. Moreover, the interaction between Ni and Al at high temperature further promotes the reaction. Both 2Ni/3Al-CF and 2Ni/3Ce-CF catalysts showed an increase in methanol conversion with increasing the reaction temperature (4.9 %–97.6 % for 2Ni/3Al-CF and 3.0 %–67.4 % for 2Ni/3Ce-CF). Compared with bimetal catalysts, the trimetallic catalyst has a much higher methanol decomposition efficiency in the range of 200–325 ℃ at all test temperatures, and it is worth mentioning that the decomposition rate of 250–275 ℃ is significantly increased, and the methanol decomposition rate can reach 99.3 % at a lower temperature of 300 ℃. The 2Ni-CF catalysts prepared with different metal additives were subjected to low-temperature kinetic tests to exclude mass- and heat-transfer effects in the methanol decomposition reaction when the methanol conversion was less than 10 %, as shown in Fig. 8E. The apparent activation energy was calculated using the Arrhenius formula for the reaction temperature of 130–190 ℃ and GHSV of 2727 h−1. From the figure, it can be observed that the apparent activation energies for methanol decomposition over Ni-based catalysts prepared with different metal precursors are significantly different. The results showed that the following order was followed by the apparent activation energies: 2Ni-CF (108.34 kJ·mol−1)> 2Ni/3Ce-CF (97.18 kJ·mol−1)> 2Ni/3Al-CF (91.93 kJ·mol−1)> 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF (84.52 kJ·mol−1), which is inversely correlates with the activity of methanol decomposition for hydrogen production. The activation energy of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalysts is the lowest, which indicates that the intrinsic kinetics is the fastest in methanol decomposition for hydrogen production. GHSV is also an important factor affecting the catalytic performance of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalysts. In order to investigate the effect of different space velocities on the catalytic performance of the 2Ni-CF catalyst, the methanol decomposition for hydrogen production was carried out over the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst at 275 ℃ with a constant methanol partial pressure and varying total flow rate of methanol and N2, as shown in Fig. 8F. The results showed that the methanol conversion and CH4 selectivity gradually decreased with the increase of space velocities, and the hydrogen selectivity significantly increased with the shorter residence time of the reactants in the catalyst bed. At the lowest GHSV, CO methanation occurs appreciably at the expense of lower CO selectivity, suggesting that CH4 is formed as secondary product in methanol decomposition. In summary, in the range of space velocity of 1363–6815 h−1, the methanol conversion was higher at 2727 h−1 with higher H2 selectivity and lower CH4 selectivity, and therefore the use of the space velocity above 2727 h−1 was the more preferred to suppress the formation of CH4 secondary byproduct. Fig. 9(A) showed the stability of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst was tested under the conditions of atmospheric pressure, temperature of 275 ℃, and space velocity of 2727 h−1. During the continuous test of 40 h, the methanol conversion rate of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst remained at a high level of 85 %, the selectivity of methane kept at about 4.6 %, and the H2 selectivity was always kept at 91.5 %. The stability test results indicate that the methanol conversion and CH4 selectivity remained in a relatively stable state. As shown in Fig. 9(B), the catalyst maintained stable activity and excellent reusability even under simulated dynamic stop-start conditions. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Fig. S2) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, Fig. S3) of the used catalyst revealed negligible coke formation and no evidence of sintering, further confirming the structural and chemical stability of the catalyst. Therefore, 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst is expected to be applicable for methanol decomposition. To better demonstrate the practical advantages of our 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst, has been added a comparative analysis of representative catalysts reported in the literature. According to the comparative data in Table 3, 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst ranks among the best-performing catalysts reported to date for methanol decomposition. 3.8 Discussion In this study, we draw on previous research results to explore the complex relationship between the catalytic performance and structure of nickel-based catalysts for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition. It is well documented that methanol decomposition is a structure-sensitive reaction, in which varying the type of metal promoters may play a critical role in the distribution of active Ni species and the concentration of surface oxygen vacancy to facilitate their synergistic effects on the catalytic process. It is widely accepted that there are two pathways occurring on different Ni crystal facets for hydrogen production in the reaction of methanol decomposition [66–68]. (1) CH3OH→CH3OH*→CH3O*→CH2O*→CHO*→CO+H2 (2) CH3OH→CH3OH*→*CH2OH→*CH2O→*CHO→CO+H2 The reaction initiates with molecular adsorption of CH3OH at nickel sites, where the first step involves preferential cleavage of the O–H bond to form methoxy (CH3O*) and adsorbed hydrogen (H*)-a process energetically favorable on Ni (111) surfaces but with distinct kinetic behaviors due to surface coordination differences. On Ni (100), the open surface structure allows for both O-H and C-H bond scissions, generating intermediates like hydroxymethyl (*CH2OH) alongside methoxy (2), whereas Ni (111) favors exclusive O-H activation (1). The subsequent abstraction of hydrogen from of methoxy to CH2O* via C-H bond breaking acts as the rate-limiting step, a key kinetic feature conserved across Ni facets but influenced by metal valence states and oxygen vacancies interactions [67,68]. These intermediates further decompose through successive hydrogen abstractions, ultimately yielding CO and H2. The structure-sensitive nature of the methanol decomposition reaction implies that nanoscale Ni dispersion and promoter-induced surface reconstruction can alter adsorption energies and reaction barriers, aligning with the observed correlation between surface area, active site density, and product selectivity in this study. In this work, the concentration of surface oxygen vacancy can be effectively tuned by adjusting the types of metal promoters to enhance their synergistic effects, and the catalytic performance of nickel-based catalysts for methanol decomposition in relation to the species distribution of Ni. A series of catalysts, including 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF, 2Ni/3Al-CF, 2Ni/3Ce-CF, and 2Ni-CF were synthesized to systematically investigate composition-dependent catalytic activities influence on H2 and CO production from methanol decomposition. SEM characterization indicated that the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst has revealed distinct signs of roughness by chemical etching on the CF surface and featured a uniform nanocrystalline porous layer, facilitating efficient mass transport. This etching phenomenon significantly increases the surface area of the catalyst. This finding is in accordance with the SBET, which also indicates an increase in the surface area. The enlarged surface area provides more active sites for the enhancement of the catalytic reaction. XPS analysis uncovered a strong correlation among oxygen vacancy concentration, the distribution of Ni species and catalytic activity, where the gradient of oxygen defect density directly mirrored the observed activity trend. This relationship followed a characteristic volcano-shaped curve, with optimal activity occurring at a 71.89 % Ni2+ ratio in the trimetallic 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst-a finding consistent with the established role of metal valence state balance in methanol decomposition [69]. The superior performance originated from the subtle balance of surface metallic Ni0 domains, which facilitated C–H bond scission, and Ni δ+ species, which favor the adsorption of methanol molecule and activation of oxygen-containing functional groups and intermediates. Past study on surface science has demonstrated that methanol interacts very weakly on single crystal of Ni(111) surface and the coverage of permanently adsorbed methanol is much higher in the presence of surface oxygen, allowing methanol decomposition to proceed more efficiently on oxygen predisposed surfaces [70]. In this sense, the methanol sticking probability may be enhanced over the cationic Ni2+ sites to promote the initial methanol adsorption. In this work, insufficient or excessive Ni2+ in 2Ni/3Ce-CF disrupted the balance of surface Ni species required for optimum catalyst, underscoring the importance of precise ternary interface engineering to optimize the Ni0/Ni2+ ratio for efficient methanol decomposition [71,72]. H2-TPR results indicated that a moderate reducibility in 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF promoted the suitable surface redox properties, characterized by high hydrogen consumption and optimal reduction kinetics—key parameters for forming stable active sites [73]. The strong correlation between metal reducibility and catalytic performance highlighted the critical role of Ni-Ce-Al interactions in shaping the redox properties of the catalyst, which in turn influenced active site formation and stability. Integrating XPS and H2-TPR data revealed a complex structure-activity relationship, where oxygen vacancies, Ni valence states, and ternary metal synergies collectively governed catalytic efficiency [74]. According to the results of CH3OH-TPD, the methanol decomposition on these four catalysts proceeds in the order of 2Ni-CF< 2Ni/3CE-CF< 2Ni/3Al-CF< 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF, which is fully consistent with their activity as shown in Fig. 8A. To sum up, the outstanding of superior activity and stability of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF arise from the synergistic effect of (1) a nanocrystalline porous structure for efficient mass transfer, (2) a balanced Ni0/NiTotal ratio to enable dual-functionality in initial methanol adsorption and C-H bond scission in rate-controlling step of methanol decomposition, and (3) abundant oxygen vacancies to enhance surface reactivity. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study reported the preparation of mono-, bi-, and trimetallic Ni-based catalysts, which are three-dimensional porous metal foam structures prepared by the chemical wet-etching method, and their application in hydrogen production via methanol decomposition within the temperature range of 200–325 ℃. The trimetallic 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF exhibited optimal activity, achieving 99.3 % methanol conversion and 91.8 % H2 selectivity at 300 ℃, outperforming bimetallic and monometallic counterparts. Characterizations revealed that etched copper foam increased surface area for active sites and synergistic Ni-Ce-Al interactions generated abundant oxygen vacancies and optimized surface Ni2+ to metallic Ni0 ratios presenting a typical volcano-type activity dependence. H2-TPR and CH3OH-TPD confirmed balanced reducibility and enhanced low-temperature methanol decomposition for hydrogen production via three-metal synergy. Stability tests showed 40 h durability at 275 ℃. The work highlights multi-metal synergies and structural optimization as key design principles for efficient methanol decomposition catalysts, providing insights for high-performance hydrogen production systems. coredata.dc:description: A series of metal foam-supported Ni-based catalysts-monometallic Ni-CF, bimetallic Ni/Ce-CF, Ni/Al-CF and trimetallic Ni/Ce/Al-CF-were prepared by modified wet chemical etching (MWCE) and employed for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition (MD) in the temperature range of 200–325 ℃. Among those catalysts, the 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-Cu foam (CF) catalyst shows the superior catalytic performance for hydrogen production, achieving a remarkable activity of almost complete methanol conversion (99.3 %) and high H2 selectivity of 91.8 % at 300 ℃. Moreover, the performance of 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF catalyst remained stable during the stability test for up to 40 h at 275 ℃. SEM and BET characterization show that etched copper foam can remarkably enlarge the specific surface area of the structured catalyst, provide more active sites, and enhance its catalytic activity. The strong interaction among Ni, Ce and Al induce the synergistic effect by creating abundant oxygen vacancies in the trimetallic system as evidenced by XPS. H2-TPR and XPS further revealed a crucial balance between reducibility and metal-support interactions: Al-containing catalysts like 2Ni/3Ce/3Al-CF exhibit higher reduction thresholds and confirming the role of Al in stabilizing oxidized Ni species via strong metal-support interactions. And CH3OH-TPD analysis indicated the catalyst had much higher low-temperature hydrogen production than other catalysts because of the synergistic effect of three metals, consistent with the catalyst activity test results. The developed strategy may provide insights into the development of the design principles for high-performance structured catalysts for hydrogen production via methanol decomposition.
